text: The Lord called to Moses and spoke to him from the tent of meeting. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Speak to the Israelites and say to them: “When anyone among you brings an offering to the Lord, bring as your offering an animal from either the herd or the flock.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“If the offering is a burnt offering from the herd, you are to offer a male without defect. You must present it at the entrance to the tent of meeting so that it will be acceptable to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to lay your hand on the head of the burnt offering, and it will be accepted on your behalf to make atonement for you.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to slaughter the young bull before the Lord, and then Aaron’s sons the priests shall bring the blood and splash it against the sides of the altar at the entrance to the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to skin the burnt offering and cut it into pieces.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Aaron the priest are to put fire on the altar and arrange wood on the fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Aaron’s sons the priests shall arrange the pieces, including the head and the fat, on the wood that is burning on the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to wash the internal organs and the legs with water, and the priest is to burn all of it on the altar. It is a burnt offering, a food offering, an aroma pleasing to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“If the offering is a burnt offering from the flock, from either the sheep or the goats, you are to offer a male without defect.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to slaughter it at the north side of the altar before the Lord, and Aaron’s sons the priests shall splash its blood against the sides of the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to cut it into pieces, and the priest shall arrange them, including the head and the fat, on the wood that is burning on the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to wash the internal organs and the legs with water, and the priest is to bring all of them and burn them on the altar. It is a burnt offering, a food offering, an aroma pleasing to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“If the offering to the Lord is a burnt offering of birds, you are to offer a dove or a young pigeon.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest shall bring it to the altar, wring off the head and burn it on the altar; its blood shall be drained out on the side of the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: He is to remove the crop and the feathers and throw them down east of the altar where the ashes are.
speaker: Narrator

text: He shall tear it open by the wings, not dividing it completely, and then the priest shall burn it on the wood that is burning on the altar. It is a burnt offering, a food offering, an aroma pleasing to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“When anyone brings a grain offering to the Lord, their offering is to be of the finest flour. They are to pour olive oil on it, put incense on it
speaker: Narrator

text: and take it to Aaron’s sons the priests. The priest shall take a handful of the flour and oil, together with all the incense, and burn this as a memorial portion on the altar, a food offering, an aroma pleasing to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of the grain offering belongs to Aaron and his sons; it is a most holy part of the food offerings presented to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“If you bring a grain offering baked in an oven, it is to consist of the finest flour: either thick loaves made without yeast and with olive oil mixed in or thin loaves made without yeast and brushed with olive oil.
speaker: Narrator

text: If your grain offering is prepared on a griddle, it is to be made of the finest flour mixed with oil, and without yeast.
speaker: Narrator

text: Crumble it and pour oil on it; it is a grain offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: If your grain offering is cooked in a pan, it is to be made of the finest flour and some olive oil.
speaker: Narrator

text: Bring the grain offering made of these things to the Lord; present it to the priest, who shall take it to the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: He shall take out the memorial portion from the grain offering and burn it on the altar as a food offering, an aroma pleasing to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of the grain offering belongs to Aaron and his sons; it is a most holy part of the food offerings presented to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“Every grain offering you bring to the Lord must be made without yeast, for you are not to burn any yeast or honey in a food offering presented to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: You may bring them to the Lord as an offering of the firstfruits, but they are not to be offered on the altar as a pleasing aroma.
speaker: Narrator

text: Season all your grain offerings with salt. Do not leave the salt of the covenant of your God out of your grain offerings; add salt to all your offerings.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“If you bring a grain offering of firstfruits to the Lord, offer crushed heads of new grain roasted in the fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: Put oil and incense on it; it is a grain offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest shall burn the memorial portion of the crushed grain and the oil, together with all the incense, as a food offering presented to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“If your offering is a fellowship offering, and you offer an animal from the herd, whether male or female, you are to present before the Lord an animal without defect.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to lay your hand on the head of your offering and slaughter it at the entrance to the tent of meeting. Then Aaron’s sons the priests shall splash the blood against the sides of the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the fellowship offering you are to bring a food offering to the Lord: the internal organs and all the fat that is connected to them,
speaker: Narrator

text: both kidneys with the fat on them near the loins, and the long lobe of the liver, which you will remove with the kidneys.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Aaron’s sons are to burn it on the altar on top of the burnt offering that is lying on the burning wood; it is a food offering, an aroma pleasing to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“If you offer an animal from the flock as a fellowship offering to the Lord, you are to offer a male or female without defect.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you offer a lamb, you are to present it before the Lord,
speaker: Narrator

text: lay your hand on its head and slaughter it in front of the tent of meeting. Then Aaron’s sons shall splash its blood against the sides of the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the fellowship offering you are to bring a food offering to the Lord: its fat, the entire fat tail cut off close to the backbone, the internal organs and all the fat that is connected to them,
speaker: Narrator

text: both kidneys with the fat on them near the loins, and the long lobe of the liver, which you will remove with the kidneys.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest shall burn them on the altar as a food offering presented to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“If your offering is a goat, you are to present it before the Lord,
speaker: Narrator

text: lay your hand on its head and slaughter it in front of the tent of meeting. Then Aaron’s sons shall splash its blood against the sides of the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: From what you offer you are to present this food offering to the Lord: the internal organs and all the fat that is connected to them,
speaker: Narrator

text: both kidneys with the fat on them near the loins, and the long lobe of the liver, which you will remove with the kidneys.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest shall burn them on the altar as a food offering, a pleasing aroma. All the fat is the Lord’s.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“This is a lasting ordinance for the generations to come, wherever you live: you must not eat any fat or any blood.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Say to the Israelites: “When anyone sins unintentionally and does what is forbidden in any of the Lord’s commands –
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“If the anointed priest sins, bringing guilt on the people, he must bring to the Lord a young bull without defect as a sin offering for the sin he has committed.
speaker: Narrator

text: He is to present the bull at the entrance to the tent of meeting before the Lord. He is to lay his hand on its head and slaughter it there before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the anointed priest shall take some of the bull’s blood and carry it into the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: He is to dip his finger into the blood and sprinkle some of it seven times before the Lord, in front of the curtain of the sanctuary.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest shall then put some of the blood on the horns of the altar of fragrant incense that is before the Lord in the tent of meeting. The rest of the bull’s blood he shall pour out at the base of the altar of burnt offering at the entrance to the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: He shall remove all the fat from the bull of the sin offering – all the fat that is connected to the internal organs,
speaker: Narrator

text: both kidneys with the fat on them near the loins, and the long lobe of the liver, which he will remove with the kidneys –
speaker: Narrator

text: just as the fat is removed from the ox sacrificed as a fellowship offering. Then the priest shall burn them on the altar of burnt offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the hide of the bull and all its flesh, as well as the head and legs, the internal organs and the intestines –
speaker: Narrator

text: that is, all the rest of the bull – he must take outside the camp to a place ceremonially clean, where the ashes are thrown, and burn it there in a wood fire on the ash heap.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“If the whole Israelite community sins unintentionally and does what is forbidden in any of the Lord’s commands, even though the community is unaware of the matter, when they realise their guilt
speaker: Narrator

text: and the sin they committed becomes known, the assembly must bring a young bull as a sin offering and present it before the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: The elders of the community are to lay their hands on the bull’s head before the Lord, and the bull shall be slaughtered before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the anointed priest is to take some of the bull’s blood into the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: He shall dip his finger into the blood and sprinkle it before the Lord seven times in front of the curtain.
speaker: Narrator

text: He is to put some of the blood on the horns of the altar that is before the Lord in the tent of meeting. The rest of the blood he shall pour out at the base of the altar of burnt offering at the entrance to the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: He shall remove all the fat from it and burn it on the altar,
speaker: Narrator

text: and do with this bull just as he did with the bull for the sin offering. In this way the priest will make atonement for the community, and they will be forgiven.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he shall take the bull outside the camp and burn it as he burned the first bull. This is the sin offering for the community.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“When a leader sins unintentionally and does what is forbidden in any of the commands of the Lord his God, when he realises his guilt
speaker: Narrator

text: and the sin he has committed becomes known, he must bring as his offering a male goat without defect.
speaker: Narrator

text: He is to lay his hand on the goat’s head and slaughter it at the place where the burnt offering is slaughtered before the Lord. It is a sin offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the priest shall take some of the blood of the sin offering with his finger and put it on the horns of the altar of burnt offering and pour out the rest of the blood at the base of the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: He shall burn all the fat on the altar as he burned the fat of the fellowship offering. In this way the priest will make atonement for the leader’s sin, and he will be forgiven.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“If any member of the community sins unintentionally and does what is forbidden in any of the Lord’s commands, when they realise their guilt
speaker: Narrator

text: and the sin they have committed becomes known, they must bring as their offering for the sin they committed a female goat without defect.
speaker: Narrator

text: They are to lay their hand on the head of the sin offering and slaughter it at the place of the burnt offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the priest is to take some of the blood with his finger and put it on the horns of the altar of burnt offering and pour out the rest of the blood at the base of the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: They shall remove all the fat, just as the fat is removed from the fellowship offering, and the priest shall burn it on the altar as an aroma pleasing to the Lord. In this way the priest will make atonement for them, and they will be forgiven.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“If someone brings a lamb as their sin offering, they are to bring a female without defect.
speaker: Narrator

text: They are to lay their hand on its head and slaughter it for a sin offering at the place where the burnt offering is slaughtered.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the priest shall take some of the blood of the sin offering with his finger and put it on the horns of the altar of burnt offering and pour out the rest of the blood at the base of the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: They shall remove all the fat, just as the fat is removed from the lamb of the fellowship offering, and the priest shall burn it on the altar on top of the food offerings presented to the Lord. In this way the priest will make atonement for them for the sin they have committed, and they will be forgiven.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“If anyone sins because they do not speak up when they hear a public charge to testify regarding something they have seen or learned about, they will be held responsible.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“If anyone becomes aware that they are guilty – if they unwittingly touch anything ceremonially unclean (whether the carcass of an unclean animal, wild or domestic, or of any unclean creature that moves along the ground) and they are unaware that they have become unclean, but then they come to realise their guilt;
speaker: Narrator

text: or if they touch human uncleanness (anything that would make them unclean) even though they are unaware of it, but then they learn of it and realise their guilt;
speaker: Narrator

text: or if anyone thoughtlessly takes an oath to do anything, whether good or evil (in any matter one might carelessly swear about) even though they are unaware of it, but then they learn of it and realise their guilt –
speaker: Narrator

text: when anyone becomes aware that they are guilty in any of these matters, they must confess in what way they have sinned.
speaker: Narrator

text: As a penalty for the sin they have committed, they must bring to the Lord a female lamb or goat from the flock as a sin offering; and the priest shall make atonement for them for their sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“Anyone who cannot afford a lamb is to bring two doves or two young pigeons to the Lord as a penalty for their sin – one for a sin offering and the other for a burnt offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: They are to bring them to the priest, who shall first offer the one for the sin offering. He is to wring its head from its neck, not dividing it completely,
speaker: Narrator

text: and is to splash some of the blood of the sin offering against the side of the altar; the rest of the blood must be drained out at the base of the altar. It is a sin offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest shall then offer the other as a burnt offering in the prescribed way and make atonement for them for the sin they have committed, and they will be forgiven.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“If, however, they cannot afford two doves or two young pigeons, they are to bring as an offering for their sin a tenth of an ephah of the finest flour for a sin offering. They must not put olive oil or incense on it, because it is a sin offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: They are to bring it to the priest, who shall take a handful of it as a memorial portion and burn it on the altar on top of the food offerings presented to the Lord. It is a sin offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: In this way the priest will make atonement for them for any of these sins they have committed, and they will be forgiven. The rest of the offering will belong to the priest, as in the case of the grain offering.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses:
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘When anyone is unfaithful to the Lord by sinning unintentionally in regard to any of the Lord’s holy things, they are to bring to the Lord as a penalty a ram from the flock, one without defect and of the proper value in silver, according to the sanctuary shekel. It is a guilt offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: They must make restitution for what they have failed to do in regard to the holy things, pay an additional penalty of a fifth of its value and give it all to the priest. The priest will make atonement for them with the ram as a guilt offering, and they will be forgiven.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘If anyone sins and does what is forbidden in any of the Lord’s commands, even though they do not know it, they are guilty and will be held responsible.
speaker: Narrator

text: They are to bring to the priest as a guilt offering a ram from the flock, one without defect and of the proper value. In this way the priest will make atonement for them for the wrong they have committed unintentionally, and they will be forgiven.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is a guilt offering; they have been guilty of wrongdoing against the Lord.’
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses:
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘If anyone sins and is unfaithful to the Lord by deceiving a neighbour about something entrusted to them or left in their care or about something stolen, or if they cheat their neighbour,
speaker: Narrator

text: or if they find lost property and lie about it, or if they swear falsely about any such sin that people may commit –
speaker: Narrator

text: when they sin in any of these ways and realise their guilt, they must return what they have stolen or taken by extortion, or what was entrusted to them, or the lost property they found,
speaker: Narrator

text: or whatever it was they swore falsely about. They must make restitution in full, add a fifth of the value to it and give it all to the owner on the day they present their guilt offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: And as a penalty they must bring to the priest, that is, to the Lord, their guilt offering, a ram from the flock, one without defect and of the proper value.
speaker: Narrator

text: In this way the priest will make atonement for them before the Lord, and they will be forgiven for any of the things they did that made them guilty.’
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses:
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Give Aaron and his sons this command: “These are the regulations for the burnt offering: the burnt offering is to remain on the altar hearth throughout the night, till morning, and the fire must be kept burning on the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest shall then put on his linen clothes, with linen undergarments next to his body, and shall remove the ashes of the burnt offering that the fire has consumed on the altar and place them beside the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he is to take off these clothes and put on others, and carry the ashes outside the camp to a place that is ceremonially clean.
speaker: Narrator

text: The fire on the altar must be kept burning; it must not go out. Every morning the priest is to add firewood and arrange the burnt offering on the fire and burn the fat of the fellowship offerings on it.
speaker: Narrator

text: The fire must be kept burning on the altar continuously; it must not go out.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“These are the regulations for the grain offering: Aaron’s sons are to bring it before the Lord, in front of the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest is to take a handful of the finest flour and some olive oil, together with all the incense on the grain offering, and burn the memorial portion on the altar as an aroma pleasing to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Aaron and his sons shall eat the rest of it, but it is to be eaten without yeast in the sanctuary area; they are to eat it in the courtyard of the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: It must not be baked with yeast; I have given it as their share of the food offerings presented to me. Like the sin offering and the guilt offering, it is most holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: Any male descendant of Aaron may eat it. For all generations to come it is his perpetual share of the food offerings presented to the Lord. Whatever touches it will become holy.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord also said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘This is the offering Aaron and his sons are to bring to the Lord on the day he is anointed: a tenth of an ephah of the finest flour as a regular grain offering, half of it in the morning and half in the evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: It must be prepared with oil on a griddle; bring it well-mixed and present the grain offering broken in pieces as an aroma pleasing to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The son who is to succeed him as anointed priest shall prepare it. It is the Lord’s perpetual share and is to be burned completely.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every grain offering of a priest shall be burned completely; it must not be eaten.’
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Say to Aaron and his sons: “These are the regulations for the sin offering: the sin offering is to be slaughtered before the Lord in the place where the burnt offering is slaughtered; it is most holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest who offers it shall eat it; it is to be eaten in the sanctuary area, in the courtyard of the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whatever touches any of the flesh will become holy, and if any of the blood is spattered on a garment, you must wash it in the sanctuary area.
speaker: Narrator

text: The clay pot that the meat is cooked in must be broken; but if it is cooked in a bronze pot, the pot is to be scoured and rinsed with water.
speaker: Narrator

text: Any male in a priest’s family may eat it; it is most holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: But any sin offering whose blood is brought into the tent of meeting to make atonement in the Holy Place must not be eaten; it must be burned.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“These are the regulations for the guilt offering, which is most holy:
speaker: Narrator

text: the guilt offering is to be slaughtered in the place where the burnt offering is slaughtered, and its blood is to be splashed against the sides of the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: All its fat shall be offered: the fat tail and the fat that covers the internal organs,
speaker: Narrator

text: both kidneys with the fat on them near the loins, and the long lobe of the liver, which is to be removed with the kidneys.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest shall burn them on the altar as a food offering presented to the Lord. It is a guilt offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: Any male in a priest’s family may eat it, but it must be eaten in the sanctuary area; it is most holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“The same law applies to both the sin offering and the guilt offering: they belong to the priest who makes atonement with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest who offers a burnt offering for anyone may keep its hide for himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every grain offering baked in an oven or cooked in a pan or on a griddle belongs to the priest who offers it,
speaker: Narrator

text: and every grain offering, whether mixed with olive oil or dry, belongs equally to all the sons of Aaron.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“These are the regulations for the fellowship offering anyone may present to the Lord:
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“If they offer it as an expression of thankfulness, then along with this thank-offering they are to offer thick loaves made without yeast and with olive oil mixed in, thin loaves made without yeast and brushed with oil, and thick loaves of the finest flour well-kneaded and with oil mixed in.
speaker: Narrator

text: Along with their fellowship offering of thanksgiving they are to present an offering with thick loaves of bread made with yeast.
speaker: Narrator

text: They are to bring one of each kind as an offering, a contribution to the Lord; it belongs to the priest who splashes the blood of the fellowship offering against the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: The meat of their fellowship offering of thanksgiving must be eaten on the day it is offered; they must leave none of it till morning.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“If, however, their offering is the result of a vow or is a freewill offering, the sacrifice shall be eaten on the day they offer it, but anything left over may be eaten on the next day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Any meat of the sacrifice left over till the third day must be burned.
speaker: Narrator

text: If any meat of the fellowship offering is eaten on the third day, the one who offered it will not be accepted. It will not be reckoned to their credit, for it has become impure; the person who eats any of it will be held responsible.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“Meat that touches anything ceremonially unclean must not be eaten; it must be burned. As for other meat, anyone ceremonially clean may eat it.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if anyone who is unclean eats any meat of the fellowship offering belonging to the Lord, they must be cut off from their people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Anyone who touches something unclean – whether human uncleanness or an unclean animal or any unclean creature that moves along the ground – and then eats any of the meat of the fellowship offering belonging to the Lord must be cut off from their people.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Say to the Israelites: “Do not eat any of the fat of cattle, sheep or goats.
speaker: Narrator

text: The fat of an animal found dead or torn by wild animals may be used for any other purpose, but you must not eat it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Anyone who eats the fat of an animal from which a food offering may be presented to the Lord must be cut off from their people.
speaker: Narrator

text: And wherever you live, you must not eat the blood of any bird or animal.
speaker: Narrator

text: Anyone who eats blood must be cut off from their people.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Say to the Israelites: “Anyone who brings a fellowship offering to the Lord is to bring part of it as their sacrifice to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: With their own hands they are to present the food offering to the Lord; they are to bring the fat, together with the breast, and wave the breast before the Lord as a wave offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest shall burn the fat on the altar, but the breast belongs to Aaron and his sons.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to give the right thigh of your fellowship offerings to the priest as a contribution.
speaker: Narrator

text: The son of Aaron who offers the blood and the fat of the fellowship offering shall have the right thigh as his share.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the fellowship offerings of the Israelites, I have taken the breast that is waved and the thigh that is presented and have given them to Aaron the priest and his sons as their perpetual share from the Israelites.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the portion of the food offerings presented to the Lord that were allotted to Aaron and his sons on the day they were presented to serve the Lord as priests.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the day they were anointed, the Lord commanded that the Israelites give this to them as their perpetual share for the generations to come.
speaker: Narrator

text: These, then, are the regulations for the burnt offering, the grain offering, the sin offering, the guilt offering, the ordination offering and the fellowship offering,
speaker: Narrator

text: which the Lord gave Moses at Mount Sinai in the Desert of Sinai on the day he commanded the Israelites to bring their offerings to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Bring Aaron and his sons, their garments, the anointing oil, the bull for the sin offering, the two rams and the basket containing bread made without yeast,
speaker: Narrator

text: and gather the entire assembly at the entrance to the tent of meeting.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses did as the Lord commanded him, and the assembly gathered at the entrance to the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said to the assembly, ‘This is what the Lord has commanded to be done.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses brought Aaron and his sons forward and washed them with water.
speaker: Narrator

text: He put the tunic on Aaron, tied the sash round him, clothed him with the robe and put the ephod on him. He also fastened the ephod with a decorative waistband, which he tied round him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He placed the breastpiece on him and put the Urim and Thummim in the breastpiece.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he placed the turban on Aaron’s head and set the gold plate, the sacred emblem, on the front of it, as the Lord commanded Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses took the anointing oil and anointed the tabernacle and everything in it, and so consecrated them.
speaker: Narrator

text: He sprinkled some of the oil on the altar seven times, anointing the altar and all its utensils and the basin with its stand, to consecrate them.
speaker: Narrator

text: He poured some of the anointing oil on Aaron’s head and anointed him to consecrate him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he brought Aaron’s sons forward, put tunics on them, tied sashes round them and fastened caps on them, as the Lord commanded Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: He then presented the bull for the sin offering, and Aaron and his sons laid their hands on its head.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses slaughtered the bull and took some of the blood, and with his finger he put it on all the horns of the altar to purify the altar. He poured out the rest of the blood at the base of the altar. So he consecrated it to make atonement for it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses also took all the fat around the internal organs, the long lobe of the liver, and both kidneys and their fat, and burned it on the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the bull with its hide and its flesh and its intestines he burned outside the camp, as the Lord commanded Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: He then presented the ram for the burnt offering, and Aaron and his sons laid their hands on its head.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses slaughtered the ram and splashed the blood against the sides of the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: He cut the ram into pieces and burned the head, the pieces and the fat.
speaker: Narrator

text: He washed the internal organs and the legs with water and burned the whole ram on the altar. It was a burnt offering, a pleasing aroma, a food offering presented to the Lord, as the Lord commanded Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: He then presented the other ram, the ram for the ordination, and Aaron and his sons laid their hands on its head.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses slaughtered the ram and took some of its blood and put it on the lobe of Aaron’s right ear, on the thumb of his right hand and on the big toe of his right foot.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses also brought Aaron’s sons forward and put some of the blood on the lobes of their right ears, on the thumbs of their right hands and on the big toes of their right feet. Then he splashed blood against the sides of the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: After that, he took the fat, the fat tail, all the fat around the internal organs, the long lobe of the liver, both kidneys and their fat and the right thigh.
speaker: Narrator

text: And from the basket of bread made without yeast, which was before the Lord, he took one thick loaf, one thick loaf with olive oil mixed in, and one thin loaf, and he put these on the fat portions and on the right thigh.
speaker: Narrator

text: He put all these in the hands of Aaron and his sons and they waved them before the Lord as a wave offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses took them from their hands and burned them on the altar on top of the burnt offering as an ordination offering, a pleasing aroma, a food offering presented to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses also took the breast, which was his share of the ordination ram, and waved it before the Lord as a wave offering, as the Lord commanded Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses took some of the anointing oil and some of the blood from the altar and sprinkled them on Aaron and his garments and on his sons and their garments. So he consecrated Aaron and his garments and his sons and their garments.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses then said to Aaron and his sons, ‘Cook the meat at the entrance to the tent of meeting and eat it there with the bread from the basket of ordination offerings, as I was commanded: “Aaron and his sons are to eat it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then burn the rest of the meat and the bread.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not leave the entrance to the tent of meeting for seven days, until the days of your ordination are completed, for your ordination will last seven days.
speaker: Narrator

text: What has been done today was commanded by the Lord to make atonement for you.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must stay at the entrance to the tent of meeting day and night for seven days and do what the Lord requires, so that you will not die; for that is what I have been commanded.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So Aaron and his sons did everything the Lord commanded through Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the eighth day Moses summoned Aaron and his sons and the elders of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to Aaron, ‘Take a bull calf for your sin offering and a ram for your burnt offering, both without defect, and present them before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then say to the Israelites: “Take a male goat for a sin offering, a calf and a lamb – both a year old and without defect – for a burnt offering,
speaker: Narrator

text: and an ox and a ram for a fellowship offering to sacrifice before the Lord, together with a grain offering mixed with olive oil. For today the Lord will appear to you.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: They took the things Moses commanded to the front of the tent of meeting, and the entire assembly came near and stood before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses said, ‘This is what the Lord has commanded you to do, so that the glory of the Lord may appear to you.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said to Aaron, ‘Come to the altar and sacrifice your sin offering and your burnt offering and make atonement for yourself and the people; sacrifice the offering that is for the people and make atonement for them, as the Lord has commanded.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So Aaron came to the altar and slaughtered the calf as a sin offering for himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: His sons brought the blood to him, and he dipped his finger into the blood and put it on the horns of the altar; the rest of the blood he poured out at the base of the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the altar he burned the fat, the kidneys and the long lobe of the liver from the sin offering, as the Lord commanded Moses;
speaker: Narrator

text: the flesh and the hide he burned outside the camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he slaughtered the burnt offering. His sons handed him the blood, and he splashed it against the sides of the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: They handed him the burnt offering piece by piece, including the head, and he burned them on the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: He washed the internal organs and the legs and burned them on top of the burnt offering on the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Aaron then brought the offering that was for the people. He took the goat for the people’s sin offering and slaughtered it and offered it for a sin offering as he did with the first one.
speaker: Narrator

text: He brought the burnt offering and offered it in the prescribed way.
speaker: Narrator

text: He also brought the grain offering, took a handful of it and burned it on the altar in addition to the morning’s burnt offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: He slaughtered the ox and the ram as the fellowship offering for the people. His sons handed him the blood, and he splashed it against the sides of the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the fat portions of the ox and the ram – the fat tail, the layer of fat, the kidneys and the long lobe of the liver –
speaker: Narrator

text: these they laid on the breasts, and then Aaron burned the fat on the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Aaron waved the breasts and the right thigh before the Lord as a wave offering, as Moses commanded.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Aaron lifted his hands towards the people and blessed them. And having sacrificed the sin offering, the burnt offering and the fellowship offering, he stepped down.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses and Aaron then went into the tent of meeting. When they came out, they blessed the people; and the glory of the Lord appeared to all the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Fire came out from the presence of the Lord and consumed the burnt offering and the fat portions on the altar. And when all the people saw it, they shouted for joy and fell face down.
speaker: Narrator

text: Aaron’s sons Nadab and Abihu took their censers, put fire in them and added incense; and they offered unauthorised fire before the Lord, contrary to his command.
speaker: Narrator

text: So fire came out from the presence of the Lord and consumed them, and they died before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Moses then said to Aaron, ‘This is what the Lord spoke of when he said:
‘“Among those who approach me
    I will be proved holy;
in the sight of all the people
    I will be honoured.”’
Aaron remained silent.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses summoned Mishael and Elzaphan, sons of Aaron’s uncle Uzziel, and said to them, ‘Come here; carry your cousins outside the camp, away from the front of the sanctuary.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So they came and carried them, still in their tunics, outside the camp, as Moses ordered.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses said to Aaron and his sons Eleazar and Ithamar, ‘Do not let your hair become unkempt and do not tear your clothes or you will die and the Lord will be angry with the whole community. But your relatives, all the Israelites, may mourn for those the Lord has destroyed by fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not leave the entrance to the tent of meeting or you will die, because the Lord’s anointing oil is on you.’ So they did as Moses said.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Aaron,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘You and your sons are not to drink wine or other fermented drink whenever you go into the tent of meeting, or you will die. This is a lasting ordinance for the generations to come,
speaker: Narrator

text: so that you can distinguish between the holy and the common, between the unclean and the clean,
speaker: Narrator

text: and so you can teach the Israelites all the decrees the Lord has given them through Moses.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said to Aaron and his remaining sons, Eleazar and Ithamar, ‘Take the grain offering left over from the food offerings prepared without yeast and presented to the Lord and eat it beside the altar, for it is most holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: Eat it in the sanctuary area, because it is your share and your sons’ share of the food offerings presented to the Lord; for so I have been commanded.
speaker: Narrator

text: But you and your sons and your daughters may eat the breast that was waved and the thigh that was presented. Eat them in a ceremonially clean place; they have been given to you and your children as your share of the Israelites’ fellowship offerings.
speaker: Narrator

text: The thigh that was presented and the breast that was waved must be brought with the fat portions of the food offerings, to be waved before the Lord as a wave offering. This will be the perpetual share for you and your children, as the Lord has commanded.’
speaker: Narrator

text: When Moses enquired about the goat of the sin offering and found that it had been burned, he was angry with Eleazar and Ithamar, Aaron’s remaining sons, and asked,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Why didn’t you eat the sin offering in the sanctuary area? It is most holy; it was given to you to take away the guilt of the community by making atonement for them before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Since its blood was not taken into the Holy Place, you should have eaten the goat in the sanctuary area, as I commanded.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Aaron replied to Moses, ‘Today they sacrificed their sin offering and their burnt offering before the Lord, but such things as this have happened to me. Would the Lord have been pleased if I had eaten the sin offering today?’
speaker: Narrator

text: When Moses heard this, he was satisfied.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses and Aaron,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Say to the Israelites: “Of all the animals that live on land, these are the ones you may eat:
speaker: Narrator

text: you may eat any animal that has a divided hoof and that chews the cud.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“There are some that only chew the cud or only have a divided hoof, but you must not eat them. The camel, though it chews the cud, does not have a divided hoof; it is ceremonially unclean for you.
speaker: Narrator

text: The hyrax, though it chews the cud, does not have a divided hoof; it is unclean for you.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rabbit, though it chews the cud, does not have a divided hoof; it is unclean for you.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the pig, though it has a divided hoof, does not chew the cud; it is unclean for you.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must not eat their meat or touch their carcasses; they are unclean for you.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“Of all the creatures living in the water of the seas and the streams you may eat any that have fins and scales.
speaker: Narrator

text: But all creatures in the seas or streams that do not have fins and scales – whether among all the swarming things or among all the other living creatures in the water – you are to regard as unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: And since you are to regard them as unclean, you must not eat their meat; you must regard their carcasses as unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: Anything living in the water that does not have fins and scales is to be regarded as unclean by you.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“These are the birds you are to regard as unclean and not eat because they are unclean: the eagle, the vulture, the black vulture,
speaker: Narrator

text: the red kite, any kind of black kite,
speaker: Narrator

text: any kind of raven,
speaker: Narrator

text: the horned owl, the screech owl, the gull, any kind of hawk,
speaker: Narrator

text: the little owl, the cormorant, the great owl,
speaker: Narrator

text: the white owl, the desert owl, the osprey,
speaker: Narrator

text: the stork, any kind of heron, the hoopoe and the bat.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“All flying insects that walk on all fours are to be regarded as unclean by you.
speaker: Narrator

text: There are, however, some flying insects that walk on all fours that you may eat: those that have jointed legs for hopping on the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: Of these you may eat any kind of locust, cricket, cicada or grasshopper.
speaker: Narrator

text: But all other flying insects that have four legs you are to regard as unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“You will make yourselves unclean by these; whoever touches their carcasses will be unclean till evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whoever picks up one of their carcasses must wash their clothes, and they will be unclean till evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“Every animal that does not have a divided hoof or that does not chew the cud is unclean for you; whoever touches the carcass of any of them will be unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: Of all the animals that walk on all fours, those that walk on their paws are unclean for you; whoever touches their carcasses will be unclean till evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: Anyone who picks up their carcasses must wash their clothes, and they will be unclean till evening. These animals are unclean for you.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“Of the animals that move along the ground, these are unclean for you: the weasel, the rat, any kind of great lizard,
speaker: Narrator

text: the gecko, the monitor lizard, the wall lizard, the skink and the chameleon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Of all those that move along the ground, these are unclean for you. Whoever touches them when they are dead will be unclean till evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: When one of them dies and falls on something, that article, whatever its use, will be unclean, whether it is made of wood, cloth, hide or sackcloth. Put it in water; it will be unclean till evening, and then it will be clean.
speaker: Narrator

text: If one of them falls into a clay pot, everything in it will be unclean, and you must break the pot.
speaker: Narrator

text: Any food you are allowed to eat that has come into contact with water from any such pot is unclean, and any liquid that is drunk from such a pot is unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: Anything that one of their carcasses falls on becomes unclean; an oven or cooking pot must be broken up. They are unclean, and you are to regard them as unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: A spring, however, or a cistern for collecting water remains clean, but anyone who touches one of these carcasses is unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: If a carcass falls on any seeds that are to be planted, they remain clean.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if water has been put on the seed and a carcass falls on it, it is unclean for you.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“If an animal that you are allowed to eat dies, anyone who touches its carcass will be unclean till evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: Anyone who eats some of its carcass must wash their clothes, and they will be unclean till evening. Anyone who picks up the carcass must wash their clothes, and they will be unclean till evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“Every creature that moves along the ground is to be regarded as unclean; it is not to be eaten.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are not to eat any creature that moves along the ground, whether it moves on its belly or walks on all fours or on many feet; it is unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not defile yourselves by any of these creatures. Do not make yourselves unclean by means of them or be made unclean by them.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am the Lord your God; consecrate yourselves and be holy, because I am holy. Do not make yourselves unclean by any creature that moves along the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am the Lord, who brought you up out of Egypt to be your God; therefore be holy, because I am holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“These are the regulations concerning animals, birds, every living thing that moves about in the water and every creature that moves along the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must distinguish between the unclean and the clean, between living creatures that may be eaten and those that may not be eaten.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Say to the Israelites: “A woman who becomes pregnant and gives birth to a son will be ceremonially unclean for seven days, just as she is unclean during her monthly period.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the eighth day the boy is to be circumcised.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the woman must wait thirty-three days to be purified from her bleeding. She must not touch anything sacred or go to the sanctuary until the days of her purification are over.
speaker: Narrator

text: If she gives birth to a daughter, for two weeks the woman will be unclean, as during her period. Then she must wait sixty-six days to be purified from her bleeding.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“When the days of her purification for a son or daughter are over, she is to bring to the priest at the entrance to the tent of meeting a year-old lamb for a burnt offering and a young pigeon or a dove for a sin offering.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He shall offer them before the Lord to make atonement for her, and then she will be ceremonially clean from her flow of blood.
‘“These are the regulations for the woman who gives birth to a boy or a girl.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if she cannot afford a lamb, she is to bring two doves or two young pigeons, one for a burnt offering and the other for a sin offering. In this way the priest will make atonement for her, and she will be clean.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses and Aaron,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘When anyone has a swelling or a rash or a shiny spot on their skin that may be a defiling skin disease, they must be brought to Aaron the priest or to one of his sons who is a priest.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest is to examine the sore on the skin, and if the hair in the sore has turned white and the sore appears to be more than skin deep, it is a defiling skin disease. When the priest examines that person, he shall pronounce them ceremonially unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: If the shiny spot on the skin is white but does not appear to be more than skin deep and the hair in it has not turned white, the priest is to isolate the affected person for seven days.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the seventh day the priest is to examine them, and if he sees that the sore is unchanged and has not spread in the skin, he is to isolate them for another seven days.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the seventh day the priest is to examine them again, and if the sore has faded and has not spread in the skin, the priest shall pronounce them clean; it is only a rash. They must wash their clothes, and they will be clean.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if the rash does spread in their skin after they have shown themselves to the priest to be pronounced clean, they must appear before the priest again.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest is to examine that person, and if the rash has spread in the skin, he shall pronounce them unclean; it is a defiling skin disease.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘When anyone has a defiling skin disease, they must be brought to the priest.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest is to examine them, and if there is a white swelling in the skin that has turned the hair white and if there is raw flesh in the swelling,
speaker: Narrator

text: it is a chronic skin disease and the priest shall pronounce them unclean. He is not to isolate them, because they are already unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘If the disease breaks out all over their skin and, so far as the priest can see, it covers all the skin of the affected person from head to foot,
speaker: Narrator

text: the priest is to examine them, and if the disease has covered their whole body, he shall pronounce them clean. Since it has all turned white, they are clean.
speaker: Narrator

text: But whenever raw flesh appears on them, they will be unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the priest sees the raw flesh, he shall pronounce them unclean. The raw flesh is unclean; they have a defiling disease.
speaker: Narrator

text: If the raw flesh changes and turns white, they must go to the priest.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest is to examine them, and if the sores have turned white, the priest shall pronounce the affected person clean; then they will be clean.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘When someone has a boil on their skin and it heals,
speaker: Narrator

text: and in the place where the boil was, a white swelling or reddish-white spot appears, they must present themselves to the priest.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest is to examine it, and if it appears to be more than skin deep and the hair in it has turned white, the priest shall pronounce that person unclean. It is a defiling skin disease that has broken out where the boil was.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if, when the priest examines it, there is no white hair in it and it is not more than skin deep and has faded, then the priest is to isolate them for seven days.
speaker: Narrator

text: If it is spreading in the skin, the priest shall pronounce them unclean; it is a defiling disease.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if the spot is unchanged and has not spread, it is only a scar from the boil, and the priest shall pronounce them clean.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘When someone has a burn on their skin and a reddish-white or white spot appears in the raw flesh of the burn,
speaker: Narrator

text: the priest is to examine the spot, and if the hair in it has turned white, and it appears to be more than skin deep, it is a defiling disease that has broken out in the burn. The priest shall pronounce them unclean; it is a defiling skin disease.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if the priest examines it and there is no white hair in the spot and if it is not more than skin deep and has faded, then the priest is to isolate them for seven days.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the seventh day the priest is to examine that person, and if it is spreading in the skin, the priest shall pronounce them unclean; it is a defiling skin disease.
speaker: Narrator

text: If, however, the spot is unchanged and has not spread in the skin but has faded, it is a swelling from the burn, and the priest shall pronounce them clean; it is only a scar from the burn.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘If a man or woman has a sore on their head or chin,
speaker: Narrator

text: the priest is to examine the sore, and if it appears to be more than skin deep and the hair in it is yellow and thin, the priest shall pronounce them unclean; it is a defiling skin disease on the head or chin.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if, when the priest examines the sore, it does not seem to be more than skin deep and there is no black hair in it, then the priest is to isolate the affected person for seven days.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the seventh day the priest is to examine the sore, and if it has not spread and there is no yellow hair in it and it does not appear to be more than skin deep,
speaker: Narrator

text: then the man or woman must shave themselves, except for the affected area, and the priest is to keep them isolated another seven days.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the seventh day the priest is to examine the sore, and if it has not spread in the skin and appears to be no more than skin deep, the priest shall pronounce them clean. They must wash their clothes, and they will be clean.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if the sore does spread in the skin after they are pronounced clean,
speaker: Narrator

text: the priest is to examine them, and if he finds that the sore has spread in the skin, he does not need to look for yellow hair; they are unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: If, however, the sore is unchanged so far as the priest can see, and if black hair has grown in it, the affected person is healed. They are clean, and the priest shall pronounce them clean.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘When a man or woman has white spots on the skin,
speaker: Narrator

text: the priest is to examine them, and if the spots are dull white, it is a harmless rash that has broken out on the skin; they are clean.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘A man who has lost his hair and is bald is clean.
speaker: Narrator

text: If he has lost his hair from the front of his scalp and has a bald forehead, he is clean.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if he has a reddish-white sore on his bald head or forehead, it is a defiling disease breaking out on his head or forehead.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest is to examine him, and if the swollen sore on his head or forehead is reddish-white like a defiling skin disease,
speaker: Narrator

text: the man is diseased and is unclean. The priest shall pronounce him unclean because of the sore on his head.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Anyone with such a defiling disease must wear torn clothes, let their hair be unkempt, cover the lower part of their face and cry out, “Unclean! Unclean!”
speaker: Narrator

text: As long as they have the disease they remain unclean. They must live alone; they must live outside the camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘As for any fabric that is spoiled with a defiling mould – any woollen or linen clothing,
speaker: Narrator

text: any woven or knitted material of linen or wool, any leather or anything made of leather –
speaker: Narrator

text: if the affected area in the fabric, the leather, the woven or knitted material, or any leather article, is greenish or reddish, it is a defiling mould and must be shown to the priest.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest is to examine the affected area and isolate the article for seven days.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the seventh day he is to examine it, and if the mould has spread in the fabric, the woven or knitted material, or the leather, whatever its use, it is a persistent defiling mould; the article is unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: He must burn the fabric, the woven or knitted material of wool or linen, or any leather article that has been spoiled, because the defiling mould is persistent; the article must be burned.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘But if, when the priest examines it, the mould has not spread in the fabric, the woven or knitted material, or the leather article,
speaker: Narrator

text: he shall order that the spoiled article be washed. Then he is to isolate it for another seven days.
speaker: Narrator

text: After the article has been washed, the priest is to examine it again, and if the mould has not changed its appearance, even though it has not spread, it is unclean. Burn it, no matter which side of the fabric has been spoiled.
speaker: Narrator

text: If, when the priest examines it, the mould has faded after the article has been washed, he is to tear the spoiled part out of the fabric, the leather, or the woven or knitted material.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if it reappears in the fabric, in the woven or knitted material, or in the leather article, it is a spreading mould; whatever has the mould must be burned.
speaker: Narrator

text: Any fabric, woven or knitted material, or any leather article that has been washed and is rid of the mould, must be washed again. Then it will be clean.’
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the regulations concerning defiling moulds in woollen or linen clothing, woven or knitted material, or any leather article, for pronouncing them clean or unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘These are the regulations for any diseased person at the time of their ceremonial cleansing, when they are brought to the priest:
speaker: Narrator

text: the priest is to go outside the camp and examine them. If they have been healed of their defiling skin disease,
speaker: Narrator

text: the priest shall order that two live clean birds and some cedar wood, scarlet yarn and hyssop be brought for the person to be cleansed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the priest shall order that one of the birds be killed over fresh water in a clay pot.
speaker: Narrator

text: He is then to take the live bird and dip it, together with the cedar wood, the scarlet yarn and the hyssop, into the blood of the bird that was killed over the fresh water.
speaker: Narrator

text: Seven times he shall sprinkle the one to be cleansed of the defiling disease, and then pronounce them clean. After that, he is to release the live bird in the open fields.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘The person to be cleansed must wash their clothes, shave off all their hair and bathe with water; then they will be ceremonially clean. After this they may come into the camp, but they must stay outside their tent for seven days.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the seventh day they must shave off all their hair; they must shave their head, their beard, their eyebrows and the rest of their hair. They must wash their clothes and bathe themselves with water, and they will be clean.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘On the eighth day they must bring two male lambs and one ewe lamb a year old, each without defect, along with three-tenths of an ephah of the finest flour mixed with olive oil for a grain offering, and one log of oil.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest who pronounces them clean shall present both the one to be cleansed and their offerings before the Lord at the entrance to the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Then the priest is to take one of the male lambs and offer it as a guilt offering, along with the log of oil; he shall wave them before the Lord as a wave offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: He is to slaughter the lamb in the sanctuary area where the sin offering and the burnt offering are slaughtered. Like the sin offering, the guilt offering belongs to the priest; it is most holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest is to take some of the blood of the guilt offering and put it on the lobe of the right ear of the one to be cleansed, on the thumb of their right hand and on the big toe of their right foot.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest shall then take some of the log of oil, pour it in the palm of his own left hand,
speaker: Narrator

text: dip his right forefinger into the oil in his palm, and with his finger sprinkle some of it before the Lord seven times.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest is to put some of the oil remaining in his palm on the lobe of the right ear of the one to be cleansed, on the thumb of their right hand and on the big toe of their right foot, on top of the blood of the guilt offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of the oil in his palm the priest shall put on the head of the one to be cleansed and make atonement for them before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Then the priest is to sacrifice the sin offering and make atonement for the one to be cleansed from their uncleanness. After that, the priest shall slaughter the burnt offering
speaker: Narrator

text: and offer it on the altar, together with the grain offering, and make atonement for them, and they will be clean.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘If, however, they are poor and cannot afford these, they must take one male lamb as a guilt offering to be waved to make atonement for them, together with a tenth of an ephah of the finest flour mixed with olive oil for a grain offering, a log of oil,
speaker: Narrator

text: and two doves or two young pigeons, such as they can afford, one for a sin offering and the other for a burnt offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘On the eighth day they must bring them for their cleansing to the priest at the entrance to the tent of meeting, before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest is to take the lamb for the guilt offering, together with the log of oil, and wave them before the Lord as a wave offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: He shall slaughter the lamb for the guilt offering and take some of its blood and put it on the lobe of the right ear of the one to be cleansed, on the thumb of their right hand and on the big toe of their right foot.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest is to pour some of the oil into the palm of his own left hand,
speaker: Narrator

text: and with his right forefinger sprinkle some of the oil from his palm seven times before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some of the oil in his palm he is to put on the same places he put the blood of the guilt offering – on the lobe of the right ear of the one to be cleansed, on the thumb of their right hand and on the big toe of their right foot.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of the oil in his palm the priest shall put on the head of the one to be cleansed, to make atonement for them before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he shall sacrifice the doves or the young pigeons, such as the person can afford,
speaker: Narrator

text: one as a sin offering and the other as a burnt offering, together with the grain offering. In this way the priest will make atonement before the Lord on behalf of the one to be cleansed.’
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the regulations for anyone who has a defiling skin disease and who cannot afford the usual offerings for their cleansing.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses and Aaron,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘When you enter the land of Canaan, which I am giving you as your possession, and I put a spreading mould in a house in that land,
speaker: Narrator

text: the owner of the house must go and tell the priest, “I have seen something that looks like a defiling mould in my house.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest is to order the house to be emptied before he goes in to examine the mould, so that nothing in the house will be pronounced unclean. After this the priest is to go in and inspect the house.
speaker: Narrator

text: He is to examine the mould on the walls, and if it has greenish or reddish depressions that appear to be deeper than the surface of the wall,
speaker: Narrator

text: the priest shall go out of the doorway of the house and close it up for seven days.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the seventh day the priest shall return to inspect the house. If the mould has spread on the walls,
speaker: Narrator

text: he is to order that the contaminated stones be torn out and thrown into an unclean place outside the town.
speaker: Narrator

text: He must have all the inside walls of the house scraped and the material that is scraped off dumped into an unclean place outside the town.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they are to take other stones to replace these and take new clay and plaster the house.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘If the defiling mould reappears in the house after the stones have been torn out and the house scraped and plastered,
speaker: Narrator

text: the priest is to go and examine it and, if the mould has spread in the house, it is a persistent defiling mould; the house is unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: It must be torn down – its stones, timbers and all the plaster – and taken out of the town to an unclean place.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Anyone who goes into the house while it is closed up will be unclean till evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: Anyone who sleeps or eats in the house must wash their clothes.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘But if the priest comes to examine it and the mould has not spread after the house has been plastered, he shall pronounce the house clean, because the defiling mould is gone.
speaker: Narrator

text: To purify the house he is to take two birds and some cedar wood, scarlet yarn and hyssop.
speaker: Narrator

text: He shall kill one of the birds over fresh water in a clay pot.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he is to take the cedar wood, the hyssop, the scarlet yarn and the live bird, dip them into the blood of the dead bird and the fresh water, and sprinkle the house seven times.
speaker: Narrator

text: He shall purify the house with the bird’s blood, the fresh water, the live bird, the cedar wood, the hyssop and the scarlet yarn.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he is to release the live bird in the open fields outside the town. In this way he will make atonement for the house, and it will be clean.’
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the regulations for any defiling skin disease, for a sore,
speaker: Narrator

text: for defiling moulds in fabric or in a house,
speaker: Narrator

text: and for a swelling, a rash or a shiny spot,
speaker: Narrator

text:
to determine when something is clean or unclean.
These are the regulations for defiling skin diseases and defiling moulds.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses and Aaron,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Speak to the Israelites and say to them: “When any man has an unusual bodily discharge, such a discharge is unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whether it continues flowing from his body or is blocked, it will make him unclean. This is how his discharge will bring about uncleanness:
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“Any bed the man with a discharge lies on will be unclean, and anything he sits on will be unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: Anyone who touches his bed must wash their clothes and bathe with water, and they will be unclean till evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whoever sits on anything that the man with a discharge sat on must wash their clothes and bathe with water, and they will be unclean till evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“Whoever touches the man who has a discharge must wash their clothes and bathe with water, and they will be unclean till evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“If the man with the discharge spits on anyone who is clean, they must wash their clothes and bathe with water, and they will be unclean till evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“Everything the man sits on when riding will be unclean,
speaker: Narrator

text: and whoever touches any of the things that were under him will be unclean till evening; whoever picks up those things must wash their clothes and bathe with water, and they will be unclean till evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“Anyone the man with a discharge touches without rinsing his hands with water must wash their clothes and bathe with water, and they will be unclean till evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“A clay pot that the man touches must be broken, and any wooden article is to be rinsed with water.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“When a man is cleansed from his discharge, he is to count seven days for his ceremonial cleansing; he must wash his clothes and bathe himself with fresh water, and he will be clean.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the eighth day he must take two doves or two young pigeons and come before the Lord to the entrance to the tent of meeting and give them to the priest.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest is to sacrifice them, the one for a sin offering and the other for a burnt offering. In this way he will make atonement before the Lord for the man because of his discharge.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“When a man has an emission of semen, he must bathe his whole body with water, and he will be unclean till evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: Any clothing or leather that has semen on it must be washed with water, and it will be unclean till evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: When a man has sexual relations with a woman and there is an emission of semen, both of them must bathe with water, and they will be unclean till evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“When a woman has her regular flow of blood, the impurity of her monthly period will last seven days, and anyone who touches her will be unclean till evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“Anything she lies on during her period will be unclean, and anything she sits on will be unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: Anyone who touches her bed will be unclean; they must wash their clothes and bathe with water, and they will be unclean till evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: Anyone who touches anything she sits on will be unclean; they must wash their clothes and bathe with water, and they will be unclean till evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whether it is the bed or anything she was sitting on, when anyone touches it, they will be unclean till evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“If a man has sexual relations with her and her monthly flow touches him, he will be unclean for seven days; any bed he lies on will be unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“When a woman has a discharge of blood for many days at a time other than her monthly period or has a discharge that continues beyond her period, she will be unclean as long as she has the discharge, just as in the days of her period.
speaker: Narrator

text: Any bed she lies on while her discharge continues will be unclean, as is her bed during her monthly period, and anything she sits on will be unclean, as during her period.
speaker: Narrator

text: Anyone who touches them will be unclean; they must wash their clothes and bathe with water, and they will be unclean till evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“When she is cleansed from her discharge, she must count seven days, and after that she will be ceremonially clean.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the eighth day she must take two doves or two young pigeons and bring them to the priest at the entrance to the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest is to sacrifice one for a sin offering and the other for a burnt offering. In this way he will make atonement for her before the Lord for the uncleanness of her discharge.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“You must keep the Israelites separate from things that make them unclean, so they will not die in their uncleanness for defiling my dwelling-place, which is among them.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the regulations for a man with a discharge, for anyone made unclean by an emission of semen,
speaker: Narrator

text: for a woman in her monthly period, for a man or a woman with a discharge, and for a man who has sexual relations with a woman who is ceremonially unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Moses after the death of the two sons of Aaron who died when they approached the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses: ‘Tell your brother Aaron that he is not to come whenever he chooses into the Most Holy Place behind the curtain in front of the atonement cover on the ark, or else he will die. For I will appear in the cloud over the atonement cover.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘This is how Aaron is to enter the Most Holy Place: he must first bring a young bull for a sin offering and a ram for a burnt offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: He is to put on the sacred linen tunic, with linen undergarments next to his body; he is to tie the linen sash round him and put on the linen turban. These are sacred garments; so he must bathe himself with water before he puts them on.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the Israelite community he is to take two male goats for a sin offering and a ram for a burnt offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Aaron is to offer the bull for his own sin offering to make atonement for himself and his household.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he is to take the two goats and present them before the Lord at the entrance to the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: He is to cast lots for the two goats – one lot for the Lord and the other for the scapegoat.
speaker: Narrator

text: Aaron shall bring the goat whose lot falls to the Lord and sacrifice it for a sin offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the goat chosen by lot as the scapegoat shall be presented alive before the Lord to be used for making atonement by sending it into the wilderness as a scapegoat.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Aaron shall bring the bull for his own sin offering to make atonement for himself and his household, and he is to slaughter the bull for his own sin offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: He is to take a censer full of burning coals from the altar before the Lord and two handfuls of finely ground fragrant incense and take them behind the curtain.
speaker: Narrator

text: He is to put the incense on the fire before the Lord, and the smoke of the incense will conceal the atonement cover above the tablets of the covenant law, so that he will not die.
speaker: Narrator

text: He is to take some of the bull’s blood and with his finger sprinkle it on the front of the atonement cover; then he shall sprinkle some of it with his finger seven times before the atonement cover.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘He shall then slaughter the goat for the sin offering for the people and take its blood behind the curtain and do with it as he did with the bull’s blood: he shall sprinkle it on the atonement cover and in front of it.
speaker: Narrator

text: In this way he will make atonement for the Most Holy Place because of the uncleanness and rebellion of the Israelites, whatever their sins have been. He is to do the same for the tent of meeting, which is among them in the midst of their uncleanness.
speaker: Narrator

text: No one is to be in the tent of meeting from the time Aaron goes in to make atonement in the Most Holy Place until he comes out, having made atonement for himself, his household and the whole community of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Then he shall come out to the altar that is before the Lord and make atonement for it. He shall take some of the bull’s blood and some of the goat’s blood and put it on all the horns of the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: He shall sprinkle some of the blood on it with his finger seven times to cleanse it and consecrate it from the uncleanness of the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘When Aaron has finished making atonement for the Most Holy Place, the tent of meeting and the altar, he shall bring forward the live goat.
speaker: Narrator

text: He is to lay both hands on the head of the live goat and confess over it all the wickedness and rebellion of the Israelites – all their sins – and put them on the goat’s head. He shall send the goat away into the wilderness in the care of someone appointed for the task.
speaker: Narrator

text: The goat will carry on itself all their sins to a remote place; and the man shall release it in the wilderness.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Then Aaron is to go into the tent of meeting and take off the linen garments he put on before he entered the Most Holy Place, and he is to leave them there.
speaker: Narrator

text: He shall bathe himself with water in the sanctuary area and put on his ordinary garments. Then he shall come out and sacrifice the burnt offering for himself and the burnt offering for the people, to make atonement for himself and for the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: He shall also burn the fat of the sin offering on the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘The man who releases the goat as a scapegoat must wash his clothes and bathe himself with water; afterwards he may come into the camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: The bull and the goat for the sin offerings, whose blood was brought into the Most Holy Place to make atonement, must be taken outside the camp; their hides, flesh and intestines are to be burned.
speaker: Narrator

text: The man who burns them must wash his clothes and bathe himself with water; afterwards he may come into the camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘This is to be a lasting ordinance for you: on the tenth day of the seventh month you must deny yourselves and not do any work – whether native-born or a foreigner residing among you –
speaker: Narrator

text: because on this day atonement will be made for you, to cleanse you. Then, before the Lord, you will be clean from all your sins.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is a day of sabbath rest, and you must deny yourselves; it is a lasting ordinance.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest who is anointed and ordained to succeed his father as high priest is to make atonement. He is to put on the sacred linen garments
speaker: Narrator
