text: and make atonement for the Most Holy Place, for the tent of meeting and the altar, and for the priests and all the members of the community.
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘This is to be a lasting ordinance for you: atonement is to be made once a year for all the sins of the Israelites.’
And it was done, as the Lord commanded Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Speak to Aaron and his sons and to all the Israelites and say to them: “This is what the Lord has commanded:
speaker: Narrator

text: any Israelite who sacrifices an ox, a lamb or a goat in the camp or outside it
speaker: Narrator

text: instead of bringing it to the entrance to the tent of meeting to present it as an offering to the Lord in front of the tabernacle of the Lord – that person shall be considered guilty of bloodshed; they have shed blood and must be cut off from their people.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is so that the Israelites will bring to the Lord the sacrifices they are now making in the open fields. They must bring them to the priest, that is, to the Lord, at the entrance to the tent of meeting and sacrifice them as fellowship offerings.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest is to splash the blood against the altar of the Lord at the entrance to the tent of meeting and burn the fat as an aroma pleasing to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: They must no longer offer any of their sacrifices to the goat idols to whom they prostitute themselves. This is to be a lasting ordinance for them and for the generations to come.”
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Say to them: “Any Israelite or any foreigner residing among them who offers a burnt offering or sacrifice
speaker: Narrator

text: and does not bring it to the entrance to the tent of meeting to sacrifice it to the Lord must be cut off from the people of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“I will set my face against any Israelite or any foreigner residing among them who eats blood, and I will cut them off from the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the life of a creature is in the blood, and I have given it to you to make atonement for yourselves on the altar; it is the blood that makes atonement for one’s life.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore I say to the Israelites, ‘None of you may eat blood, nor may any foreigner residing among you eat blood.’
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“Any Israelite or any foreigner residing among you who hunts any animal or bird that may be eaten must drain out the blood and cover it with earth,
speaker: Narrator

text: because the life of every creature is its blood. That is why I have said to the Israelites, ‘You must not eat the blood of any creature, because the life of every creature is its blood; anyone who eats it must be cut off.’
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“Anyone, whether native-born or foreigner, who eats anything found dead or torn by wild animals must wash their clothes and bathe with water, and they will be ceremonially unclean till evening; then they will be clean.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if they do not wash their clothes and bathe themselves, they will be held responsible.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Speak to the Israelites and say to them: “I am the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must not do as they do in Egypt, where you used to live, and you must not do as they do in the land of Canaan, where I am bringing you. Do not follow their practices.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must obey my laws and be careful to follow my decrees. I am the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Keep my decrees and laws, for the person who obeys them will live by them. I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“No one is to approach any close relative to have sexual relations. I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“Do not dishonour your father by having sexual relations with your mother. She is your mother; do not have relations with her.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“Do not have sexual relations with your father’s wife; that would dishonour your father.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“Do not have sexual relations with your sister, either your father’s daughter or your mother’s daughter, whether she was born in the same home or elsewhere.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“Do not have sexual relations with your son’s daughter or your daughter’s daughter; that would dishonour you.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“Do not have sexual relations with the daughter of your father’s wife, born to your father; she is your sister.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“Do not have sexual relations with your father’s sister; she is your father’s close relative.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“Do not have sexual relations with your mother’s sister, because she is your mother’s close relative.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“Do not dishonour your father’s brother by approaching his wife to have sexual relations; she is your aunt.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“Do not have sexual relations with your daughter-in-law. She is your son’s wife; do not have relations with her.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“Do not have sexual relations with your brother’s wife; that would dishonour your brother.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“Do not have sexual relations with both a woman and her daughter. Do not have sexual relations with either her son’s daughter or her daughter’s daughter; they are her close relatives. That is wickedness.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“Do not take your wife’s sister as a rival wife and have sexual relations with her while your wife is living.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“Do not approach a woman to have sexual relations during the uncleanness of her monthly period.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“Do not have sexual relations with your neighbour’s wife and defile yourself with her.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“Do not give any of your children to be sacrificed to Molek, for you must not profane the name of your God. I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“Do not have sexual relations with a man as one does with a woman; that is detestable.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“Do not have sexual relations with an animal and defile yourself with it. A woman must not present herself to an animal to have sexual relations with it; that is a perversion.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“Do not defile yourselves in any of these ways, because this is how the nations that I am going to drive out before you became defiled.
speaker: Narrator

text: Even the land was defiled; so I punished it for its sin, and the land vomited out its inhabitants.
speaker: Narrator

text: But you must keep my decrees and my laws. The native-born and the foreigners residing among you must not do any of these detestable things,
speaker: Narrator

text: for all these things were done by the people who lived in the land before you, and the land became defiled.
speaker: Narrator

text: And if you defile the land, it will vomit you out as it vomited out the nations that were before you.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“Everyone who does any of these detestable things – such persons must be cut off from their people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Keep my requirements and do not follow any of the detestable customs that were practised before you came and do not defile yourselves with them. I am the Lord your God.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Speak to the entire assembly of Israel and say to them: “Be holy because I, the Lord your God, am holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“Each of you must respect your mother and father, and you must observe my Sabbaths. I am the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“Do not turn to idols or make metal gods for yourselves. I am the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“When you sacrifice a fellowship offering to the Lord, sacrifice it in such a way that it will be accepted on your behalf.
speaker: Narrator

text: It shall be eaten on the day you sacrifice it or on the next day; anything left over until the third day must be burned.
speaker: Narrator

text: If any of it is eaten on the third day, it is impure and will not be accepted.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whoever eats it will be held responsible because they have desecrated what is holy to the Lord; they must be cut off from their people.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“When you reap the harvest of your land, do not reap to the very edges of your field or gather the gleanings of your harvest.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not go over your vineyard a second time or pick up the grapes that have fallen. Leave them for the poor and the foreigner. I am the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘“Do not steal.
‘“Do not lie.
‘“Do not deceive one another.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“Do not swear falsely by my name and so profane the name of your God. I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘“Do not defraud or rob your neighbour.
‘“Do not hold back the wages of a hired worker overnight.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“Do not curse the deaf or put a stumbling-block in front of the blind, but fear your God. I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“Do not pervert justice; do not show partiality to the poor or favouritism to the great, but judge your neighbour fairly.
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘“Do not go about spreading slander among your people.
‘“Do not do anything that endangers your neighbour’s life. I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“Do not hate a fellow Israelite in your heart. Rebuke your neighbour frankly so that you will not share in their guilt.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“Do not seek revenge or bear a grudge against anyone among your people, but love your neighbour as yourself. I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘“Keep my decrees.
‘“Do not mate different kinds of animals.
‘“Do not plant your field with two kinds of seed.
‘“Do not wear clothing woven of two kinds of material.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“If a man sleeps with a female slave who is promised to another man but who has not been ransomed or given her freedom, there must be due punishment. Yet they are not to be put to death, because she had not been freed.
speaker: Narrator

text: The man, however, must bring a ram to the entrance to the tent of meeting for a guilt offering to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: With the ram of the guilt offering the priest is to make atonement for him before the Lord for the sin he has committed, and his sin will be forgiven.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“When you enter the land and plant any kind of fruit tree, regard its fruit as forbidden. For three years you are to consider it forbidden; it must not be eaten.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the fourth year all its fruit will be holy, an offering of praise to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: But in the fifth year you may eat its fruit. In this way your harvest will be increased. I am the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘“Do not eat any meat with the blood still in it.
‘“Do not practise divination or seek omens.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“Do not cut the hair at the sides of your head or clip off the edges of your beard.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“Do not cut your bodies for the dead or put tattoo marks on yourselves. I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“Do not degrade your daughter by making her a prostitute, or the land will turn to prostitution and be filled with wickedness.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“Observe my Sabbaths and have reverence for my sanctuary. I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“Do not turn to mediums or seek out spiritists, for you will be defiled by them. I am the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“Stand up in the presence of the aged, show respect for the elderly and revere your God. I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“When a foreigner resides among you in your land, do not ill-treat them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The foreigner residing among you must be treated as your native-born. Love them as yourself, for you were foreigners in Egypt. I am the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“Do not use dishonest standards when measuring length, weight or quantity.
speaker: Narrator

text: Use honest scales and honest weights, an honest ephah and an honest hin. I am the Lord your God, who brought you out of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“Keep all my decrees and all my laws and follow them. I am the Lord.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Say to the Israelites: “Any Israelite or any foreigner residing in Israel who sacrifices any of his children to Molek is to be put to death. The members of the community are to stone him.
speaker: Narrator

text: I myself will set my face against him and will cut him off from his people; for by sacrificing his children to Molek, he has defiled my sanctuary and profaned my holy name.
speaker: Narrator

text: If the members of the community close their eyes when that man sacrifices one of his children to Molek and if they fail to put him to death,
speaker: Narrator

text: I myself will set my face against him and his family and will cut them off from their people together with all who follow him in prostituting themselves to Molek.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“I will set my face against anyone who turns to mediums and spiritists to prostitute themselves by following them, and I will cut them off from their people.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“Consecrate yourselves and be holy, because I am the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Keep my decrees and follow them. I am the Lord, who makes you holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“Anyone who curses their father or mother is to be put to death. Because they have cursed their father or mother, their blood will be on their own head.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“If a man commits adultery with another man’s wife – with the wife of his neighbour – both the adulterer and the adulteress are to be put to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“If a man has sexual relations with his father’s wife, he has dishonoured his father. Both the man and the woman are to be put to death; their blood will be on their own heads.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“If a man has sexual relations with his daughter-in-law, both of them are to be put to death. What they have done is a perversion; their blood will be on their own heads.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“If a man has sexual relations with a man as one does with a woman, both of them have done what is detestable. They are to be put to death; their blood will be on their own heads.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“If a man marries both a woman and her mother, it is wicked. Both he and they must be burned in the fire, so that no wickedness will be among you.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“If a man has sexual relations with an animal, he is to be put to death, and you must kill the animal.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“If a woman approaches an animal to have sexual relations with it, kill both the woman and the animal. They are to be put to death; their blood will be on their own heads.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“If a man marries his sister, the daughter of either his father or his mother, and they have sexual relations, it is a disgrace. They are to be publicly removed from their people. He has dishonoured his sister and will be held responsible.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“If a man has sexual relations with a woman during her monthly period, he has exposed the source of her flow, and she has also uncovered it. Both of them are to be cut off from their people.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“Do not have sexual relations with the sister of either your mother or your father, for that would dishonour a close relative; both of you would be held responsible.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“If a man has sexual relations with his aunt, he has dishonoured his uncle. They will be held responsible; they will die childless.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“If a man marries his brother’s wife, it is an act of impurity; he has dishonoured his brother. They will be childless.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“Keep all my decrees and laws and follow them, so that the land where I am bringing you to live may not vomit you out.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must not live according to the customs of the nations I am going to drive out before you. Because they did all these things, I abhorred them.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I said to you, ‘You will possess their land; I will give it to you as an inheritance, a land flowing with milk and honey.’ I am the Lord your God, who has set you apart from the nations.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“You must therefore make a distinction between clean and unclean animals and between unclean and clean birds. Do not defile yourselves by any animal or bird or anything that moves along the ground – those that I have set apart as unclean for you.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to be holy to me because I, the Lord, am holy, and I have set you apart from the nations to be my own.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“A man or woman who is a medium or spiritist among you must be put to death. You are to stone them; their blood will be on their own heads.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, ‘Speak to the priests, the sons of Aaron, and say to them: “A priest must not make himself ceremonially unclean for any of his people who die,
speaker: Narrator

text: except for a close relative, such as his mother or father, his son or daughter, his brother,
speaker: Narrator

text: or an unmarried sister who is dependent on him since she has no husband – for her he may make himself unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: He must not make himself unclean for people related to him by marriage, and so defile himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“Priests must not shave their heads or shave off the edges of their beards or cut their bodies.
speaker: Narrator

text: They must be holy to their God and must not profane the name of their God. Because they present the food offerings to the Lord, the food of their God, they are to be holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“They must not marry women defiled by prostitution or divorced from their husbands, because priests are holy to their God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Regard them as holy, because they offer up the food of your God. Consider them holy, because I the Lord am holy – I who make you holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“If a priest’s daughter defiles herself by becoming a prostitute, she disgraces her father; she must be burned in the fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“The high priest, the one among his brothers who has had the anointing oil poured on his head and who has been ordained to wear the priestly garments, must not let his hair become unkempt or tear his clothes.
speaker: Narrator

text: He must not enter a place where there is a dead body. He must not make himself unclean, even for his father or mother,
speaker: Narrator

text: nor leave the sanctuary of his God or desecrate it, because he has been dedicated by the anointing oil of his God. I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“The woman he marries must be a virgin.
speaker: Narrator

text: He must not marry a widow, a divorced woman, or a woman defiled by prostitution, but only a virgin from his own people,
speaker: Narrator

text: so that he will not defile his offspring among his people. I am the Lord, who makes him holy.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Say to Aaron: “For the generations to come none of your descendants who has a defect may come near to offer the food of his God.
speaker: Narrator

text: No man who has any defect may come near: no man who is blind or lame, disfigured or deformed;
speaker: Narrator

text: no man with a crippled foot or hand,
speaker: Narrator

text: or who is a hunchback or a dwarf, or who has any eye defect, or who has festering or running sores or damaged testicles.
speaker: Narrator

text: No descendant of Aaron the priest who has any defect is to come near to present the food offerings to the Lord. He has a defect; he must not come near to offer the food of his God.
speaker: Narrator

text: He may eat the most holy food of his God, as well as the holy food;
speaker: Narrator

text: yet because of his defect, he must not go near the curtain or approach the altar, and so desecrate my sanctuary. I am the Lord, who makes them holy.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses told this to Aaron and his sons and to all the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Tell Aaron and his sons to treat with respect the sacred offerings the Israelites consecrate to me, so that they will not profane my holy name. I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Say to them: “For the generations to come, if any of your descendants is ceremonially unclean and yet comes near the sacred offerings that the Israelites consecrate to the Lord, that person must be cut off from my presence. I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“If a descendant of Aaron has a defiling skin disease or a bodily discharge, he may not eat the sacred offerings until he is cleansed. He will also be unclean if he touches something defiled by a corpse or by anyone who has an emission of semen,
speaker: Narrator

text: or if he touches any crawling thing that makes him unclean, or any person who makes him unclean, whatever the uncleanness may be.
speaker: Narrator

text: The one who touches any such thing will be unclean till evening. He must not eat any of the sacred offerings unless he has bathed himself with water.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the sun goes down, he will be clean, and after that he may eat the sacred offerings, for they are his food.
speaker: Narrator

text: He must not eat anything found dead or torn by wild animals, and so become unclean through it. I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“The priests are to perform my service in such a way that they do not become guilty and die for treating it with contempt. I am the Lord, who makes them holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“No one outside a priest’s family may eat the sacred offering, nor may the guest of a priest or his hired worker eat it.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if a priest buys a slave with money, or if slaves are born in his household, they may eat his food.
speaker: Narrator

text: If a priest’s daughter marries anyone other than a priest, she may not eat any of the sacred contributions.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if a priest’s daughter becomes a widow or is divorced, yet has no children, and she returns to live in her father’s household as in her youth, she may eat her father’s food. No unauthorised person, however, may eat it.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“Anyone who eats a sacred offering by mistake must make restitution to the priest for the offering and add a fifth of the value to it.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priests must not desecrate the sacred offerings the Israelites present to the Lord
speaker: Narrator

text: by allowing them to eat the sacred offerings and so bring upon them guilt requiring payment. I am the Lord, who makes them holy.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Speak to Aaron and his sons and to all the Israelites and say to them: “If any of you – whether an Israelite or a foreigner residing in Israel – presents a gift for a burnt offering to the Lord, either to fulfil a vow or as a freewill offering,
speaker: Narrator

text: you must present a male without defect from the cattle, sheep or goats in order that it may be accepted on your behalf.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not bring anything with a defect, because it will not be accepted on your behalf.
speaker: Narrator

text: When anyone brings from the herd or flock a fellowship offering to the Lord to fulfil a special vow or as a freewill offering, it must be without defect or blemish to be acceptable.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not offer to the Lord the blind, the injured or the maimed, or anything with warts or festering or running sores. Do not place any of these on the altar as a food offering presented to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: You may, however, present as a freewill offering an ox or a sheep that is deformed or stunted, but it will not be accepted in fulfilment of a vow.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must not offer to the Lord an animal whose testicles are bruised, crushed, torn or cut. You must not do this in your own land,
speaker: Narrator

text: and you must not accept such animals from the hand of a foreigner and offer them as the food of your God. They will not be accepted on your behalf, because they are deformed and have defects.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘When a calf, a lamb or a goat is born, it is to remain with its mother for seven days. From the eighth day on, it will be acceptable as a food offering presented to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not slaughter a cow or a sheep and its young on the same day.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘When you sacrifice a thank-offering to the Lord, sacrifice it in such a way that it will be accepted on your behalf.
speaker: Narrator

text: It must be eaten that same day; leave none of it till morning. I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Keep my commands and follow them. I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not profane my holy name, for I must be acknowledged as holy by the Israelites. I am the Lord, who made you holy
speaker: Narrator

text: and who brought you out of Egypt to be your God. I am the Lord.’
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Speak to the Israelites and say to them: “These are my appointed festivals, the appointed festivals of the Lord, which you are to proclaim as sacred assemblies.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“There are six days when you may work, but the seventh day is a day of sabbath rest, a day of sacred assembly. You are not to do any work; wherever you live, it is a sabbath to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“These are the Lord’s appointed festivals, the sacred assemblies you are to proclaim at their appointed times:
speaker: Narrator

text: the Lord’s Passover begins at twilight on the fourteenth day of the first month.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the fifteenth day of that month the Lord’s Festival of Unleavened Bread begins; for seven days you must eat bread made without yeast.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the first day hold a sacred assembly and do not do any of your ordinary work.
speaker: Narrator

text: For seven days present a food offering to the Lord. And on the seventh day hold a sacred assembly and do not do any of your ordinary work.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Speak to the Israelites and say to them: “When you enter the land I am going to give you and you reap its harvest, bring to the priest a sheaf of the first grain you harvest.
speaker: Narrator

text: He is to wave the sheaf before the Lord so it will be accepted on your behalf; the priest is to wave it on the day after the Sabbath.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the day you wave the sheaf, you must sacrifice as a burnt offering to the Lord a lamb a year old without defect,
speaker: Narrator

text: together with its grain offering of one fifth of an ephah of the finest flour mixed with olive oil – a food offering presented to the Lord, a pleasing aroma – and its drink offering of a quarter of a hin of wine.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must not eat any bread, or roasted or new grain, until the very day you bring this offering to your God. This is to be a lasting ordinance for the generations to come, wherever you live.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“From the day after the Sabbath, the day you brought the sheaf of the wave offering, count seven full weeks.
speaker: Narrator

text: Count fifty days up to the day after the seventh Sabbath, and then present an offering of new grain to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: From wherever you live, bring two loaves made of one fifth of an ephah of the finest flour, baked with yeast, as a wave offering of firstfruits to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Present with this bread seven male lambs, each a year old and without defect, one young bull and two rams. They will be a burnt offering to the Lord, together with their grain offerings and drink offerings – a food offering, an aroma pleasing to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then sacrifice one male goat for a sin offering and two lambs, each a year old, for a fellowship offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest is to wave the two lambs before the Lord as a wave offering, together with the bread of the firstfruits. They are a sacred offering to the Lord for the priest.
speaker: Narrator

text: On that same day you are to proclaim a sacred assembly and not do any ordinary work. This is to be a lasting ordinance for the generations to come, wherever you live.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“When you reap the harvest of your land, do not reap to the very edges of your field or gather the gleanings of your harvest. Leave them for the poor and for the foreigner residing among you. I am the Lord your God.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Say to the Israelites: “On the first day of the seventh month you are to have a day of sabbath rest, a sacred assembly commemorated with trumpet blasts.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not do any of your ordinary work, but present a food offering to the Lord.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘The tenth day of this seventh month is the Day of Atonement. Hold a sacred assembly and deny yourselves, and present a food offering to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not do any work on that day, because it is the Day of Atonement, when atonement is made for you before the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who do not deny themselves on that day must be cut off from their people.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will destroy from among their people anyone who does any work on that day.
speaker: Narrator

text: You shall do no work at all. This is to be a lasting ordinance for the generations to come, wherever you live.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is a day of sabbath rest for you, and you must deny yourselves. From the evening of the ninth day of the month until the following evening you are to observe your sabbath.’
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Say to the Israelites: “On the fifteenth day of the seventh month the Lord’s Festival of Tabernacles begins, and it lasts for seven days.
speaker: Narrator

text: The first day is a sacred assembly; do not do any of your ordinary work.
speaker: Narrator

text: For seven days present food offerings to the Lord, and on the eighth day hold a sacred assembly and present a food offering to the Lord. It is the closing special assembly; do not do any of your ordinary work.
speaker: Narrator

text: (‘“These are the Lord’s appointed festivals, which you are to proclaim as sacred assemblies for bringing food offerings to the Lord – the burnt offerings and grain offerings, sacrifices and drink offerings required for each day.
speaker: Narrator

text: These offerings are in addition to those for the Lord’s Sabbaths and in addition to your gifts and whatever you have vowed and all the freewill offerings you give to the Lord.)
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“So beginning with the fifteenth day of the seventh month, after you have gathered the crops of the land, celebrate the festival to the Lord for seven days; the first day is a day of sabbath rest, and the eighth day also is a day of sabbath rest.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the first day you are to take branches from luxuriant trees – from palms, willows and other leafy trees – and rejoice before the Lord your God for seven days.
speaker: Narrator

text: Celebrate this as a festival to the Lord for seven days each year. This is to be a lasting ordinance for the generations to come; celebrate it in the seventh month.
speaker: Narrator

text: Live in temporary shelters for seven days: all native-born Israelites are to live in such shelters
speaker: Narrator

text: so that your descendants will know that I made the Israelites live in temporary shelters when I brought them out of Egypt. I am the Lord your God.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses announced to the Israelites the appointed festivals of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Command the Israelites to bring you clear oil of pressed olives for the light so that the lamps may be kept burning continually.
speaker: Narrator

text: Outside the curtain that shields the ark of the covenant law in the tent of meeting, Aaron is to tend the lamps before the Lord from evening till morning, continually. This is to be a lasting ordinance for the generations to come.
speaker: Narrator

text: The lamps on the pure gold lampstand before the Lord must be tended continually.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Take the finest flour and bake twelve loaves of bread, using one fifth of an ephah for each loaf.
speaker: Narrator

text: Arrange them in two piles, six in each pile, on the table of pure gold before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: By each pile put some pure incense as a memorial portion to represent the bread and to be a food offering presented to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: This bread is to be set out before the Lord regularly, Sabbath after Sabbath, on behalf of the Israelites, as a lasting covenant.
speaker: Narrator

text: It belongs to Aaron and his sons, who are to eat it in the sanctuary area, because it is a most holy part of their perpetual share of the food offerings presented to the Lord.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the son of an Israelite mother and an Egyptian father went out among the Israelites, and a fight broke out in the camp between him and an Israelite.
speaker: Narrator

text: The son of the Israelite woman used the Name blasphemously with a curse; so they brought him to Moses. (His mother’s name was Shelomith, the daughter of Dibri the Danite.)
speaker: Narrator

text: They put him in custody until the will of the Lord should be made clear to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses:
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Take the blasphemer outside the camp. All those who heard him are to lay their hands on his head, and the entire assembly is to stone him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Say to the Israelites: “Anyone who curses their God will be held responsible;
speaker: Narrator

text: anyone who uses the name of the Lord blasphemously is to be put to death. The entire assembly must stone them. Whether foreigner or native-born, when they use the Name blasphemously they are to be put to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“Anyone who takes the life of a human being is to be put to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: Anyone who takes the life of someone’s animal must make restitution – life for life.
speaker: Narrator

text: Anyone who injures their neighbour is to be injured in the same manner:
speaker: Narrator

text: fracture for fracture, eye for eye, tooth for tooth. The one who has inflicted the injury must suffer the same injury.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whoever kills an animal must make restitution, but whoever kills a human being is to be put to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to have the same law for the foreigner and the native-born. I am the Lord your God.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses spoke to the Israelites, and they took the blasphemer outside the camp and stoned him. The Israelites did as the Lord commanded Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses at Mount Sinai,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Speak to the Israelites and say to them: “When you enter the land I am going to give you, the land itself must observe a sabbath to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: For six years sow your fields, and for six years prune your vineyards and gather their crops.
speaker: Narrator

text: But in the seventh year the land is to have a year of sabbath rest, a sabbath to the Lord. Do not sow your fields or prune your vineyards.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not reap what grows of itself or harvest the grapes of your untended vines. The land is to have a year of rest.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whatever the land yields during the sabbath year will be food for you – for yourself, your male and female servants, and the hired worker and temporary resident who live among you,
speaker: Narrator

text: as well as for your livestock and the wild animals in your land. Whatever the land produces may be eaten.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“Count seven sabbath years – seven times seven years – so that the seven sabbath years amount to a period of forty-nine years.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then sound the trumpet everywhere on the tenth day of the seventh month; on the Day of Atonement sound the trumpet throughout your land.
speaker: Narrator

text: Consecrate the fiftieth year and proclaim liberty throughout the land to all its inhabitants. It shall be a jubilee for you; each of you is to return to your family property and to your own clan.
speaker: Narrator

text: The fiftieth year shall be a jubilee for you; do not sow and do not reap what grows of itself or harvest the untended vines.
speaker: Narrator

text: For it is a jubilee and is to be holy for you; eat only what is taken directly from the fields.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“In this Year of Jubilee everyone is to return to their own property.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“If you sell land to any of your own people or buy land from them, do not take advantage of each other.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to buy from your own people on the basis of the number of years since the Jubilee. And they are to sell to you on the basis of the number of years left for harvesting crops.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the years are many, you are to increase the price, and when the years are few, you are to decrease the price, because what is really being sold to you is the number of crops.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not take advantage of each other, but fear your God. I am the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“Follow my decrees and be careful to obey my laws, and you will live safely in the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the land will yield its fruit, and you will eat your fill and live there in safety.
speaker: Narrator

text: You may ask, ‘What will we eat in the seventh year if we do not plant or harvest our crops?’
speaker: Narrator

text: I will send you such a blessing in the sixth year that the land will yield enough for three years.
speaker: Narrator

text: While you plant during the eighth year, you will eat from the old crop and will continue to eat from it until the harvest of the ninth year comes in.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“The land must not be sold permanently, because the land is mine and you reside in my land as foreigners and strangers.
speaker: Narrator

text: Throughout the land that you hold as a possession, you must provide for the redemption of the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“If one of your fellow Israelites becomes poor and sells some of their property, their nearest relative is to come and redeem what they have sold.
speaker: Narrator

text: If, however, there is no one to redeem it for them but later on they prosper and acquire sufficient means to redeem it themselves,
speaker: Narrator

text: they are to determine the value for the years since they sold it and refund the balance to the one to whom they sold it; they can then go back to their own property.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if they do not acquire the means to repay, what was sold will remain in the possession of the buyer until the Year of Jubilee. It will be returned in the Jubilee, and they can then go back to their property.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“Anyone who sells a house in a walled city retains the right of redemption a full year after its sale. During that time the seller may redeem it.
speaker: Narrator

text: If it is not redeemed before a full year has passed, the house in the walled city shall belong permanently to the buyer and the buyer’s descendants. It is not to be returned in the Jubilee.
speaker: Narrator

text: But houses in villages without walls round them are to be considered as belonging to the open country. They can be redeemed, and they are to be returned in the Jubilee.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“The Levites always have the right to redeem their houses in the Levitical towns, which they possess.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the property of the Levites is redeemable – that is, a house sold in any town they hold – and is to be returned in the Jubilee, because the houses in the towns of the Levites are their property among the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the pasture-land belonging to their towns must not be sold; it is their permanent possession.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“If any of your fellow Israelites become poor and are unable to support themselves among you, help them as you would a foreigner and stranger, so that they can continue to live among you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not take interest or any profit from them, but fear your God, so that they may continue to live among you.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must not lend them money at interest or sell them food at a profit.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am the Lord your God, who brought you out of Egypt to give you the land of Canaan and to be your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“If any of your fellow Israelites become poor and sell themselves to you, do not make them work as slaves.
speaker: Narrator

text: They are to be treated as hired workers or temporary residents among you; they are to work for you until the Year of Jubilee.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they and their children are to be released, and they will go back to their own clans and to the property of their ancestors.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because the Israelites are my servants, whom I brought out of Egypt, they must not be sold as slaves.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not rule over them ruthlessly, but fear your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“Your male and female slaves are to come from the nations around you; from them you may buy slaves.
speaker: Narrator

text: You may also buy some of the temporary residents living among you and members of their clans born in your country, and they will become your property.
speaker: Narrator

text: You can bequeath them to your children as inherited property and can make them slaves for life, but you must not rule over your fellow Israelites ruthlessly.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“If a foreigner residing among you becomes rich and any of your fellow Israelites become poor and sell themselves to the foreigner or to a member of the foreigner’s clan,
speaker: Narrator

text: they retain the right of redemption after they have sold themselves. One of their relatives may redeem them:
speaker: Narrator

text: an uncle or a cousin or any blood-relative in their clan may redeem them. Or if they prosper, they may redeem themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: They and their buyer are to count the time from the year they sold themselves up to the Year of Jubilee. The price for their release is to be based on the rate paid to a hired worker for that number of years.
speaker: Narrator

text: If many years remain, they must pay for their redemption a larger share of the price paid for them.
speaker: Narrator

text: If only a few years remain until the Year of Jubilee, they are to compute that and pay for their redemption accordingly.
speaker: Narrator

text: They are to be treated as workers hired from year to year; you must see to it that those to whom they owe service do not rule over them ruthlessly.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“Even if someone is not redeemed in any of these ways, they and their children are to be released in the Year of Jubilee,
speaker: Narrator

text: for the Israelites belong to me as servants. They are my servants, whom I brought out of Egypt. I am the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“Do not make idols or set up an image or a sacred stone for yourselves, and do not place a carved stone in your land to bow down before it. I am the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“Observe my Sabbaths and have reverence for my sanctuary. I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“If you follow my decrees and are careful to obey my commands,
speaker: Narrator

text: I will send you rain in its season, and the ground will yield its crops and the trees their fruit.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your threshing will continue until grape harvest and the grape harvest will continue until planting, and you will eat all the food you want and live in safety in your land.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“I will grant peace in the land, and you will lie down and no one will make you afraid. I will remove wild beasts from the land, and the sword will not pass through your country.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will pursue your enemies, and they will fall by the sword before you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Five of you will chase a hundred, and a hundred of you will chase ten thousand, and your enemies will fall by the sword before you.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“I will look on you with favour and make you fruitful and increase your numbers, and I will keep my covenant with you.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will still be eating last year’s harvest when you will have to move it out to make room for the new.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will put my dwelling-place among you, and I will not abhor you.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will walk among you and be your God, and you will be my people.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am the Lord your God, who brought you out of Egypt so that you would no longer be slaves to the Egyptians; I broke the bars of your yoke and enabled you to walk with heads held high.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“But if you will not listen to me and carry out all these commands,
speaker: Narrator

text: and if you reject my decrees and abhor my laws and fail to carry out all my commands and so violate my covenant,
speaker: Narrator

text: then I will do this to you: I will bring on you sudden terror, wasting diseases and fever that will destroy your sight and sap your strength. You will plant seed in vain, because your enemies will eat it.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will set my face against you so that you will be defeated by your enemies; those who hate you will rule over you, and you will flee even when no one is pursuing you.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“If after all this you will not listen to me, I will punish you for your sins seven times over.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will break down your stubborn pride and make the sky above you like iron and the ground beneath you like bronze.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your strength will be spent in vain, because your soil will not yield its crops, nor will the trees of your land yield their fruit.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“If you remain hostile towards me and refuse to listen to me, I will multiply your afflictions seven times over, as your sins deserve.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will send wild animals against you, and they will rob you of your children, destroy your cattle and make you so few in number that your roads will be deserted.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“If in spite of these things you do not accept my correction but continue to be hostile towards me,
speaker: Narrator

text: I myself will be hostile towards you and will afflict you for your sins seven times over.
speaker: Narrator

text: And I will bring the sword on you to avenge the breaking of the covenant. When you withdraw into your cities, I will send a plague among you, and you will be given into enemy hands.
speaker: Narrator

text: When I cut off your supply of bread, ten women will be able to bake your bread in one oven, and they will dole out the bread by weight. You will eat, but you will not be satisfied.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“If in spite of this you still do not listen to me but continue to be hostile towards me,
speaker: Narrator

text: then in my anger I will be hostile towards you, and I myself will punish you for your sins seven times over.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will eat the flesh of your sons and the flesh of your daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will destroy your high places, cut down your incense altars and pile your dead bodies on the lifeless forms of your idols, and I will abhor you.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will turn your cities into ruins and lay waste your sanctuaries, and I will take no delight in the pleasing aroma of your offerings.
speaker: Narrator

text: I myself will lay waste the land, so that your enemies who live there will be appalled.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will scatter you among the nations and will draw out my sword and pursue you. Your land will be laid waste, and your cities will lie in ruins.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the land will enjoy its sabbath years all the time that it lies desolate and you are in the country of your enemies; then the land will rest and enjoy its sabbaths.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the time that it lies desolate, the land will have the rest it did not have during the sabbaths you lived in it.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“As for those of you who are left, I will make their hearts so fearful in the lands of their enemies that the sound of a wind-blown leaf will put them to flight. They will run as though fleeing from the sword, and they will fall, even though no one is pursuing them.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will stumble over one another as though fleeing from the sword, even though no one is pursuing them. So you will not be able to stand before your enemies.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will perish among the nations; the land of your enemies will devour you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those of you who are left will waste away in the lands of their enemies because of their sins; also because of their ancestors’ sins they will waste away.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“But if they will confess their sins and the sins of their ancestors – their unfaithfulness and their hostility towards me,
speaker: Narrator

text: which made me hostile towards them so that I sent them into the land of their enemies – then when their uncircumcised hearts are humbled and they pay for their sin,
speaker: Narrator

text: I will remember my covenant with Jacob and my covenant with Isaac and my covenant with Abraham, and I will remember the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the land will be deserted by them and will enjoy its sabbaths while it lies desolate without them. They will pay for their sins because they rejected my laws and abhorred my decrees.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet in spite of this, when they are in the land of their enemies, I will not reject them or abhor them so as to destroy them completely, breaking my covenant with them. I am the Lord their God.
speaker: Narrator

text: But for their sake I will remember the covenant with their ancestors whom I brought out of Egypt in the sight of the nations to be their God. I am the Lord.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the decrees, the laws and the regulations that the Lord established at Mount Sinai between himself and the Israelites through Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Speak to the Israelites and say to them: “If anyone makes a special vow to dedicate a person to the Lord by giving the equivalent value,
speaker: Narrator

text: set the value of a male between the ages of twenty and sixty at fifty shekels of silver, according to the sanctuary shekel;
speaker: Narrator

text: for a female, set her value at thirty shekels;
speaker: Narrator

text: for a person between the ages of five and twenty, set the value of a male at twenty shekels and of a female at ten shekels;
speaker: Narrator

text: for a person between one month and five years, set the value of a male at five shekels of silver and that of a female at three shekels of silver;
speaker: Narrator

text: for a person sixty years old or more, set the value of a male at fifteen shekels and of a female at ten shekels.
speaker: Narrator

text: If anyone making the vow is too poor to pay the specified amount, the person being dedicated is to be presented to the priest, who will set the value according to what the one making the vow can afford.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“If what they vowed is an animal that is acceptable as an offering to the Lord, such an animal given to the Lord becomes holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: They must not exchange it or substitute a good one for a bad one, or a bad one for a good one; if they should substitute one animal for another, both it and the substitute become holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: If what they vowed is a ceremonially unclean animal – one that is not acceptable as an offering to the Lord – the animal must be presented to the priest,
speaker: Narrator

text: who will judge its quality as good or bad. Whatever value the priest then sets, that is what it will be.
speaker: Narrator

text: If the owner wishes to redeem the animal, a fifth must be added to its value.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“If anyone dedicates their house as something holy to the Lord, the priest will judge its quality as good or bad. Whatever value the priest then sets, so it will remain.
speaker: Narrator

text: If the one who dedicates their house wishes to redeem it, they must add a fifth to its value, and the house will again become theirs.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“If anyone dedicates to the Lord part of their family land, its value is to be set according to the amount of seed required for it – fifty shekels of silver to a homer of barley seed.
speaker: Narrator

text: If they dedicate a field during the Year of Jubilee, the value that has been set remains.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if they dedicate a field after the Jubilee, the priest will determine the value according to the number of years that remain until the next Year of Jubilee, and its set value will be reduced.
speaker: Narrator

text: If the one who dedicates the field wishes to redeem it, they must add a fifth to its value, and the field will again become theirs.
speaker: Narrator

text: If, however, they do not redeem the field, or if they have sold it to someone else, it can never be redeemed.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the field is released in the Jubilee, it will become holy, like a field devoted to the Lord; it will become priestly property.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“If anyone dedicates to the Lord a field they have bought, which is not part of their family land,
speaker: Narrator

text: the priest will determine its value up to the Year of Jubilee, and the owner must pay its value on that day as something holy to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the Year of Jubilee the field will revert to the person from whom it was bought, the one whose land it was.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every value is to be set according to the sanctuary shekel, twenty gerahs to the shekel.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“No one, however, may dedicate the firstborn of an animal, since the firstborn already belongs to the Lord; whether an ox or a sheep, it is the Lord’s.
speaker: Narrator

text: If it is one of the unclean animals, it may be bought back at its set value, adding a fifth of the value to it. If it is not redeemed, it is to be sold at its set value.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“But nothing that a person owns and devotes to the Lord – whether a human being or an animal or family land – may be sold or redeemed; everything so devoted is most holy to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“No one devoted to destruction may be ransomed; they are to be put to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“A tithe of everything from the land, whether grain from the soil or fruit from the trees, belongs to the Lord; it is holy to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whoever would redeem any of their tithe must add a fifth of the value to it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every tithe of the herd and flock – every tenth animal that passes under the shepherd’s rod – will be holy to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: No one may pick out the good from the bad or make any substitution. If anyone does make a substitution, both the animal and its substitute become holy and cannot be redeemed.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the commands the Lord gave Moses at Mount Sinai for the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator
